page.title: 05DECLINE OF SHALE INDUSTRY
page.content: James Young's business reached its peak in 1868, 3.25 million tons of oil shale were being produced and 4o,000 people were employed.The industry then went into decline and by 1905 there were only 30 works operating. They amalgamated in 1919 to form Scottish Oils Ltd. The plant at Pumpherston managed to survive until 1963 when, despite by-products such as detergents, gases for lighting, petrol, wax and fertiliser, it was admitted that it was cheaper to import oil from the Persian Gulf and this forced Scottish Oils to breathe its last. Paraffin Young died in 1883 but the area of West Lothian is still benefiting from the results of his invention.
